Prospects for implementation of RTS appear dreary
By J. D. CONSIDINE
This is the third in a series of
articles on Rapid Transit in
Baltimore.
Rapid Transit, like most issues
in Baltimore, does not appear to
be much of an issue at all. Yet,
under a seemingly dreary ebb and
flow of press releases and news
conferences lies some of the most
lively wheeling and dealing in
domestic politics.
Once a community concern,
Baltimore's Rapid Transit System
(RTS) has become an only
occaisional concern for the
average citizen. The initial
ground-breaking last October
caused little more than a yawn,
and the ensuing snail's pace of
construction has caused most
Baltimoreans to believe that an
RTS will never come to be—and
they are very probably right.
State support of the RTS
project has almost dropped out
entirely. In addition to the
previously reported suggestions
from Governor Marvin Mandel
that the state will refuse to
support RTS if it is a losing
venture, Lt. Gov. Blair Lee has
announced that the strain of RTS
construction will force a freeze
on all highway construction in
the state.

It has since been rumored that
the Maryland Highway
Contractor's Association is
planning to obtain a court
injunction to prevent
construction of the RTS, in
response to Lee's statement.
Lee's motives, however, might
well be worth analysis. By
announcing the impending
stoppage of all highway
construction, Lee has presented a
possible starvation of an entire
industry. To compound the issue,
it has been pointed out that there.
are no qualified tunnel
contractors in the area, which
means that RTS will deprive
some Marylanders of their
livelihood, and take their dollars
out of state.
The other effect of the Lt.
Governor's apparent ploy will be
to create regional support for
himself.
By announcing a possible
termination of highway
construction, the areas he most
strongly affects are the outer
reaches of the state, especially
Western Maryland. Furthermore,
since RTS would be of no value
to outer Maryland, a factionalism
already felt between Baltimore
City and the extreme reaches of
the state would be exacerbated.

The motives behind Lee's
actions come more clearly into
focus when one looks at the
gubernatorial situation in
Maryland. As Lt. Gov., Lee is
next in line, should the Governor
be forced to resign. Inasmuch as
the Governor is currently under
investigation by a federal
corruption probe (which earlier
in its ancestry had nabbed
County Executive Dale Anderson
and former Vice President Spiro

Agnew), it is little wonder that
Lee is looking ahead.
Even without the aspect of
Mandel's indictment or
conviction, there is the
consideration that Mandel may
run for the Senate, which leaves
Lee in a position to run for
Governor.

prospects for RTS still seem dim.

The recent results of a
Maryland Public Interest
Research Group (MARYpirg)
comparative supermarket survey
of six area stores shows that the
two Eddie's(Greenmount and St.
Paul Sts.) charge the highest
prices for the 57-item sample.
Acme supermarket

expensive according to the
survey.

Hopkins MARYpirg volunteers,

(28th and Greenmount Ave.)
A&P (Greenmount and 33rd),
and Giant (the Rotunda

meat or produce) of the food
items.
The survey was taken by a task
force of thirteen students.. Each
store was surveyed each Friday
afternoon for four weeks. At the
end of the four weeks, the results
were tabulated. Chairing the task
force was Bill Foster, head of
consumer activities for the
Hopkins chapter of, MARYpirg.
"Two years ago, when this
survey was first run, the results
proved how one can save money
by comparison shopping. This is
a futile conclusion, for one
cannot expect people to go
shopping at six different stores
each week.
"What we are trying to do this
time is to make the student
aware of the fact that he may be
able to save money by shopping
different stores on subsequent
weeks. By taking some time out,
and checking for sales, and then
relating those items on sale to
their needs, the student can save
money.

most instances one can save

With the general increase in overhead costs and the
growing scarcity of any kind of federal funding, researchers
here have little need of any further obstacles. But,
regrettably, they have a big one to face—the ever-escalating
indirect cost recovery rate imposed by the University
administration on all outside monies raised by faculty
researchers.
Determined in conjunction with federal HEW officers, this
rate continues to grow at a rate greater than inflation, a trend
which threatens to hamper, if not stifle entirely, sponsored
research.
Three years ago, the rate was fixed at 34 per cent; thence
it was raised to 38 per cent, and last year to 48 per cent.
Sponsored Research officials here predict that the rate will
jump to 52 per cent next year, so that more than one third of
the money raised by Hopkins' faculty will be 'ultimately
returned to the University to cover "indirect costs."
The effect of this continuing escalation in the recovery
rate has been—and will continue to be—to demoralize faculty
fund-raisers, who find ever more of their hard-earned
sponsorship being appropriated by the administration. The
annual hikes have been especially devastating to researchers
working on long-term projects, who have found that the rate
has increased far beyond what it was when they first
requested research sponsorship and delineated the goals of
their projects.
Faculty in this position have found it necessary to cut
back on staff salaries to make ends meet or cut back on the
goals of their projects, a regrettable result. Some researchers
have been forced to devote more vacation, research, and
teaching time to fund-raising, in the hope that the problem of
the escalating recovery rate can be circumvented if ever larger
sponsorships are acquired.
Curiously, this problem is one of the least publicized
examples of economic concerns impacting adversely on an
academic pursuit. The University administration apparently
feels that it should avoid problems in negotiations which
involve the government, as do the the Sponsored Research
arbitrations. To tamper in such decisions would be to risk
losing federal support.
Though Hopkins does not have to fear losing faculty to
other schools—since the recovery rate is uniformly high at
private universities—iC does have to face the fact that the
quality of research here and elsewhere may deteriorate due to
a trend which the federal government and private universities
would do well to offset.

Campaign Act still has problems
By STEVE SCHULTZ
"Experience should teach us
to be most on our guard to
protect
liberty when the
Government's purposes are
beneficent. Men born to freedom
are naturally alert to repel
invasion of their liberty by
evil-minded rulers. The greatest
dangers to liberty lurk in
insidious encroachment by men
of zeal, well-meaning but without
understanding."
It is well worth pondering
these words of our great Supreme
Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis
in light of the developing
post-Watergate mentality. In its
wake, a rash of "reform" bills
have been stampeded through
local, state, and national
legislatures in what resembles a
modern day throwback to
ancient purification rites.
With bi-partisan support, both
houses of Congress had no
difficulty in passing the new
Federal Election Campaign Act
of 1974 (FECA). Proponents
argue that such legislation is
necessary in order to sever the
ties which exist between big
money and politics and, to the
rout out the corruption which is
so pervasive in high governmental
positions.
While such liberal sponsors as
Rep. Morriss Udall (D-Arizona)
claim that the FECA will cleanse
the political process, they ignore
some serious constitutional
questions that are raised. Such
criticism cannot simply be
written off as academic
nit-picking, for many sections of
this statute do represent a
substantial threat to the civil
liberties of millions of American
citizens.
First, FECA places a limitation
on the amount of money that
candidates for federal office may
spend to communicate with the
electorate. In effect, this
amounts to an abridgement of
the First Amendment right to
freedom of expression. Such a
restriction on expenditures in
campaigns has led many critics to
relabel this new federal law,"The
Incumbent Protection Act," for
identical spending ceilings are put
on the challenger as well as the
incumbent. (It must be pointed

out that the majority of the
challengers who were able to
defeat incumbents in the 1972
and 1974 congressional races did
so by spending more than this
new law would allow.) Especially
hurt will be political dissidents
whose views do not normally
receive press exposure.
Second, this bill restricts the
amount of money that one
person can contribute to political
candidates ($1,000). However,

FECA is filled with loopholes to
maintain the privileged influence
of special interests. Wealthy
contributors can still dictate to
elected officials through the
formation of "voluntary"
political funds.
Third, all candidates and
political committees are required
to keep a "detailed account" of
each contributor's "full name
and the full address of his
principal place of residence."
These records are available for
government inspection at any
time. The effect of this provision,
then, is to erode the right of
privacy. By mandating disclosure
of small contributors who cannot
possibly purchase campaign
commitments, the law will deter
many from active participation in
the political process. It will
essentially legalize past
government programs of
harassment against leftist
political groups and give added
impetus to future disruptive
campaigns. Those with radical or

unpopular stands will think twice
before adding their names to yet
another dossier.
Fourth, FECA gives public
funding to candidates and parties
for Presidential primaries,
conventions, and the general
election. The "catch," though, is
that only the Democrats and
Republicans would receive such
funding. A spokesman for the
"public-interest" group Common
Cause neatly summed up what
would be the law's effect: "There
is nothing in the Constitution
that says you cannot by law
focus the energies of the nation
into two major political parties."
The FECA effectively screens out
minor parties, while giving
welfare handouts to the two
major parties.
To be vehemently opposed to
such reformist shams does not
mean that one is against true
reforms. However, this bill
maintains the "status quo" while
fronting as a liberal "reform."
Opposition to FECA is unique, in
that the political boundaries
which normally define right and
left evaporate, being no longer
relevant to the issue. In fact, it
was an odd couple indeed who
led an unsuccessful challenge in
the U.S. Court of Appeals in
Washington—former Minnesota
Senator Eugene McCarthy and
New York's Senator James
Buckley—and are now taking
their appeal to the Supreme
Court. Natural allies in many
political battles, Common Cause
and The American Civil Liberties
Union have taken diametrically
opposed stands on the issue, with
the latter calling the law a serious
threat to constitutional rights.
If, as a result of the Watergate
affair, we are to clamp down on
political diversity and stifle free
expression, then we have learned
precious little about the workings
of a pluralist democracy.
Well-intentioned reformers have
as their goal nothing less than to
restore American government to
its people. But, in their muddled
zeal, they may instead be leading
America farther away from the
ideals of her Founding Farthers,
who believed that the citizen
possessed inherent dignity and
the right to enjoy basic liberties.

By ALAN HIRSCH
The one-man show is a
theatre-form that has gained wide
acceptance of late. The
performances of Hal Holbrook as
Mark Twain and James Whitmore
as Harry Truman have been two
of the most distinguished
theatrical displays in the last
decade and have brought .wide
acclaim to this previously
unheralded form. More than
anything else these• one-man
Shows have been characterizations, deriving their strength
from warmth and personality of
the men portrayed.
Emlyn Williams, a
distinguished British playwright
and actor, brought a different
sort of one-man show to the
Hopkins campus Sunday. Those
who went to see Williams
expecting a re-creation of the
man who "never wrote a book
that didn't sell' were
disappointed."Emlyn Williams as
Charles Dickens" was a
re-creation of the readings done
on tour by Charles Dickens in
1853, and not an attempt to
recapture the essence of the man.
Williams said his
characterization of Dickens on
the stage comes not from
research into the man but simply
from his impressions of Dickens
through his novels. "If I were
Dickens that's how I'd have done
the readings."William's purpose in
his performance was clear. His
Primary intent was simply to
entertain his audience, not to be
Dickens for an evening.
Which is not to say that
merely entertaining an audience
is bad. That was Dickens'
foremost purpose in writing, so
perhaps the most honest tribute
Williams could have paid the
author was to put on the most
entertaining show he possibly
Could. Nevertheless, while
Williams's performance was,
"Triumphant. A uniquely rich
performance," in the words of

one critic, it lacked the depth
and balance of a Dickens novel.
For only recently has the world
of literary criticism
acknowledged the presence of
these qualities in Dickens.
Resemblance
Williams, who in his make-up
bears a remarkable resemblance
to pictures of Dickens, admitted
after the show Sunday that he
does direct his efforts in the
show towards the wit of Dickens'
novels at the expense of the
pathos and sentimentality in
them. "I don't emphasize the
sentimental because today that
would be cloying," he remarked.

The selections given Sunday
for the most part poked fun at
19th Century England's high
society and bourgeois, which are
interesting as historical
counterpoints but which are alien
and irrelevant to both the
backround and humor of the
American audience of the 1970's
Sentimentality
I think Williams was wrong in
his assessment of audiences
today. There is still a place for
sentimentality in the American
Theatre. The witty, satirical
description and dialogue in
Dickens provides the texture of
the novels. Sentimentality,

Romanticism, and to some
extent, tragedy, lie at the core of
many of Dickens's novels, and it
is on this basis that I take
exception with Williams's
performance. Williams, in
attempting to convey the sense
of the man from his writings,
failed to do so, for he neglected
to make the audience aware of
what lay at the heart of Dickens's
literary endeavors—a
romantically sentimental view of
the human condition.
Balance
There was not enough of the
emotion and romantic idealism in
the performance to give the work

balance. There were not enough
powerful lines such as the closing
of A Tale of Two Cities: "It is a
far, far better thing that I do,
than I have ever done; it is a far,
far better rest that I go to than I
have ever known." Williams, in
his desire to please his audience,
gave a less than satisfying
performance. His selection of
readings did not adequately
reflect both sides of the man or
his writing. It was certainly not
Williams's performance that was
lacking, but rather the idea that a
re-creation of Dickens's tour
alone could yield a thoroughly
successful dramatic presentation.

With the general increase in overhead costs and the
growing scarcity of any kind of federal funding, researchers
here have little need of any further obstacles. But,
regrettably, they have a big one to face—the ever-escalating
indirect cost recovery rate imposed by the University
administration on all outside monies raised by faculty
researchers.
Determined in conjunction with federal HEW officers, this
rate continues to grow at a rate greater than inflation, a trend
which threatens to hamper, if not stifle entirely, sponsored
research.
Three years ago, the rate was fixed at 34 per cent; thence
it was raised to 38 per cent, and last year to 48 per cent.
Sponsored Research officials here predict that the rate will
jump to 52 per cent next year, so that more than one third of
the money raised by Hopkins' faculty will be 'ultimately
returned to the University to cover "indirect costs."
The effect of this continuing escalation in the recovery
rate has been—and will continue to be—to demoralize faculty
fund-raisers, who find ever more of their hard-earned
sponsorship being appropriated by the administration. The
annual hikes have been especially devastating to researchers
working on long-term projects, who have found that the rate
has increased far beyond what it was when they first
requested research sponsorship and delineated the goals of
their projects.
Faculty in this position have found it necessary to cut
back on staff salaries to make ends meet or cut back on the
goals of their projects, a regrettable result. Some researchers
have been forced to devote more vacation, research, and
teaching time to fund-raising, in the hope that the problem of
the escalating recovery rate can be circumvented if ever larger
sponsorships are acquired.
Curiously, this problem is one of the least publicized
examples of economic concerns impacting adversely on an
academic pursuit. The University administration apparently
feels that it should avoid problems in negotiations which
involve the government, as do the the Sponsored Research
arbitrations. To tamper in such decisions would be to risk
losing federal support.
Though Hopkins does not have to fear losing faculty to
other schools—since the recovery rate is uniformly high at
private universities—iC does have to face the fact that the
quality of research here and elsewhere may deteriorate due to
a trend which the federal government and private universities
would do well to offset.

Campaign Act still has problems
By STEVE SCHULTZ
"Experience should teach us
to be most on our guard to
protect
liberty when the
Government's purposes are
beneficent. Men born to freedom
are naturally alert to repel
invasion of their liberty by
evil-minded rulers. The greatest
dangers to liberty lurk in
insidious encroachment by men
of zeal, well-meaning but without
understanding."
It is well worth pondering
these words of our great Supreme
Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis
in light of the developing
post-Watergate mentality. In its
wake, a rash of "reform" bills
have been stampeded through
local, state, and national
legislatures in what resembles a
modern day throwback to
ancient purification rites.
With bi-partisan support, both
houses of Congress had no
difficulty in passing the new
Federal Election Campaign Act
of 1974 (FECA). Proponents
argue that such legislation is
necessary in order to sever the
ties which exist between big
money and politics and, to the
rout out the corruption which is
so pervasive in high governmental
positions.
While such liberal sponsors as
Rep. Morriss Udall (D-Arizona)
claim that the FECA will cleanse
the political process, they ignore
some serious constitutional
questions that are raised. Such
criticism cannot simply be
written off as academic
nit-picking, for many sections of
this statute do represent a
substantial threat to the civil
liberties of millions of American
citizens.
First, FECA places a limitation
on the amount of money that
candidates for federal office may
spend to communicate with the
electorate. In effect, this
amounts to an abridgement of
the First Amendment right to
freedom of expression. Such a
restriction on expenditures in
campaigns has led many critics to
relabel this new federal law,"The
Incumbent Protection Act," for
identical spending ceilings are put
on the challenger as well as the
incumbent. (It must be pointed

out that the majority of the
challengers who were able to
defeat incumbents in the 1972
and 1974 congressional races did
so by spending more than this
new law would allow.) Especially
hurt will be political dissidents
whose views do not normally
receive press exposure.
Second, this bill restricts the
amount of money that one
person can contribute to political
candidates ($1,000). However,

FECA is filled with loopholes to
maintain the privileged influence
of special interests. Wealthy
contributors can still dictate to
elected officials through the
formation of "voluntary"
political funds.
Third, all candidates and
political committees are required
to keep a "detailed account" of
each contributor's "full name
and the full address of his
principal place of residence."
These records are available for
government inspection at any
time. The effect of this provision,
then, is to erode the right of
privacy. By mandating disclosure
of small contributors who cannot
possibly purchase campaign
commitments, the law will deter
many from active participation in
the political process. It will
essentially legalize past
government programs of
harassment against leftist
political groups and give added
impetus to future disruptive
campaigns. Those with radical or

unpopular stands will think twice
before adding their names to yet
another dossier.
Fourth, FECA gives public
funding to candidates and parties
for Presidential primaries,
conventions, and the general
election. The "catch," though, is
that only the Democrats and
Republicans would receive such
funding. A spokesman for the
"public-interest" group Common
Cause neatly summed up what
would be the law's effect: "There
is nothing in the Constitution
that says you cannot by law
focus the energies of the nation
into two major political parties."
The FECA effectively screens out
minor parties, while giving
welfare handouts to the two
major parties.
To be vehemently opposed to
such reformist shams does not
mean that one is against true
reforms. However, this bill
maintains the "status quo" while
fronting as a liberal "reform."
Opposition to FECA is unique, in
that the political boundaries
which normally define right and
left evaporate, being no longer
relevant to the issue. In fact, it
was an odd couple indeed who
led an unsuccessful challenge in
the U.S. Court of Appeals in
Washington—former Minnesota
Senator Eugene McCarthy and
New York's Senator James
Buckley—and are now taking
their appeal to the Supreme
Court. Natural allies in many
political battles, Common Cause
and The American Civil Liberties
Union have taken diametrically
opposed stands on the issue, with
the latter calling the law a serious
threat to constitutional rights.
If, as a result of the Watergate
affair, we are to clamp down on
political diversity and stifle free
expression, then we have learned
precious little about the workings
of a pluralist democracy.
Well-intentioned reformers have
as their goal nothing less than to
restore American government to
its people. But, in their muddled
zeal, they may instead be leading
America farther away from the
ideals of her Founding Farthers,
who believed that the citizen
possessed inherent dignity and
the right to enjoy basic liberties.

By ALAN HIRSCH
The one-man show is a
theatre-form that has gained wide
acceptance of late. The
performances of Hal Holbrook as
Mark Twain and James Whitmore
as Harry Truman have been two
of the most distinguished
theatrical displays in the last
decade and have brought .wide
acclaim to this previously
unheralded form. More than
anything else these• one-man
Shows have been characterizations, deriving their strength
from warmth and personality of
the men portrayed.
Emlyn Williams, a
distinguished British playwright
and actor, brought a different
sort of one-man show to the
Hopkins campus Sunday. Those
who went to see Williams
expecting a re-creation of the
man who "never wrote a book
that didn't sell' were
disappointed."Emlyn Williams as
Charles Dickens" was a
re-creation of the readings done
on tour by Charles Dickens in
1853, and not an attempt to
recapture the essence of the man.
Williams said his
characterization of Dickens on
the stage comes not from
research into the man but simply
from his impressions of Dickens
through his novels. "If I were
Dickens that's how I'd have done
the readings."William's purpose in
his performance was clear. His
Primary intent was simply to
entertain his audience, not to be
Dickens for an evening.
Which is not to say that
merely entertaining an audience
is bad. That was Dickens'
foremost purpose in writing, so
perhaps the most honest tribute
Williams could have paid the
author was to put on the most
entertaining show he possibly
Could. Nevertheless, while
Williams's performance was,
"Triumphant. A uniquely rich
performance," in the words of

one critic, it lacked the depth
and balance of a Dickens novel.
For only recently has the world
of literary criticism
acknowledged the presence of
these qualities in Dickens.
Resemblance
Williams, who in his make-up
bears a remarkable resemblance
to pictures of Dickens, admitted
after the show Sunday that he
does direct his efforts in the
show towards the wit of Dickens'
novels at the expense of the
pathos and sentimentality in
them. "I don't emphasize the
sentimental because today that
would be cloying," he remarked.

The selections given Sunday
for the most part poked fun at
19th Century England's high
society and bourgeois, which are
interesting as historical
counterpoints but which are alien
and irrelevant to both the
backround and humor of the
American audience of the 1970's
Sentimentality
I think Williams was wrong in
his assessment of audiences
today. There is still a place for
sentimentality in the American
Theatre. The witty, satirical
description and dialogue in
Dickens provides the texture of
the novels. Sentimentality,

Romanticism, and to some
extent, tragedy, lie at the core of
many of Dickens's novels, and it
is on this basis that I take
exception with Williams's
performance. Williams, in
attempting to convey the sense
of the man from his writings,
failed to do so, for he neglected
to make the audience aware of
what lay at the heart of Dickens's
literary endeavors—a
romantically sentimental view of
the human condition.
Balance
There was not enough of the
emotion and romantic idealism in
the performance to give the work

balance. There were not enough
powerful lines such as the closing
of A Tale of Two Cities: "It is a
far, far better thing that I do,
than I have ever done; it is a far,
far better rest that I go to than I
have ever known." Williams, in
his desire to please his audience,
gave a less than satisfying
performance. His selection of
readings did not adequately
reflect both sides of the man or
his writing. It was certainly not
Williams's performance that was
lacking, but rather the idea that a
re-creation of Dickens's tour
